CatDescriptText: Carol Bricklemyer, student, Jeannette and James R. Conley, salesman, Zelienople, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, March 19, 1960, pg. A1 with question: "Do you approve of teachers paddling children?" Ms. Bricklemyer's answer reads: "No, I don't.  During my high school days, a teacher paddled a girl student and got into a lot of trouble.  There are other things better than paddling, for instance, making a child make a toy, picture, or do some manual work."  Mr. Conley's answer reads: "I guess it's a good think because the child understands.  That's if the rewards and punishments are immediate, not drawn out."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Carol Bricklemyer wearing textured overcoat, holding books, standing in front of building; Portrait of James R. Conley wearing dark fedora and houndstooth overcoat, standing in front of building with ribbed wall
